thread.title: Pac-12 After Dark is a catchy slogan with a crowd-killing impact: Issues & Answers
thread.title_full: Pac-12 After Dark is a catchy slogan with a crowd-killing impact: Issues & Answers | OregonLive.com

author: Ken Goe | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Pac-12 After Dark is a catchy slogan with a crowd-killing impact: Issues & Answers
text:
One of the benefits of the Pac-12's television deal was supposed to be increased national exposure.
I would say that joke is on Colorado and Oregon State, which played a game Saturday that began at 7:30 p.m., 10:30 p.m. on the East Coast.
How many people tuned into that?
Sure, the game matched two teams at the bottom of the conference standings, and probably wouldn't have been widely viewed even if played in the afternoon.
But an afternoon game on a warm, sunny day, like Saturday, would have drawn more fans to Reser Stadium.
The official attendance was 36,977. I don't doubt that figure accurately reflects tickets distributed for the game. But it's laughable to believe that many people actually attended.
Forcing the Beavers to play a steady diet of late night games is killing home attendance for OSU, which has few local hotel options and a fan base that comes from some distance.
At some point, people are simply going to stop buying tickets for games that are scheduled only to provide live, late-night television programming.
I know some readers of this blog are sick of the subject. Too bad. I'm going to keep hammering on it until the nail starts to sink in.
This week, Arizona plays at Washington in a game scheduled to start 8 p.m.
OK, Pac-12's television partners ponied up big bucks to earn the right to dictate the schedule. But I think that is a long-term loser if the conference winds up curtailing home attendance.
The conference needs to take a more proactive stance to minimize the damage the start times are doing.
